Award.AwardTitle: VOSS: Teams Emerging from the Crowd: Virtual Team Structure as a Predictor of Idea Goodness in Online Innovation Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Innovation is a core driver of the U.S. economy. Organizations are constantly seeking to be more innovative with fewer resources. Advanced information and communication technologies that allow organizations to extract good ideas for products, services, and policies from the diverse suggestions of user communities represent one way to increase innovation without a concomitant increase in resource expenditures. But the outsourcing of idea generation to non-specialists increases the variance in the quality and applicability of the ideas that are generated and, concordantly, strains an organization's ability to give equal attention to all suggestions. The goal of this study is to explore how organizations might more effectively harness "the power of the crowd" to find and recognize the most promising ideas within a sea of contributions.

Recently, a good deal of research into team design has shown that the structural composition of a team can explain variations in the team's ability to generate good ideas. Conceptualizing a collective of crowd-soucing voters as an "emergent virtual team" allows us to explore a number of hypotheses about when the ideas that are voted to be "good" by emergent virtual teams with particular structures will, in fact, be the ideas upon which an organization should spend its limited resources of attention. In this two-year project, we collect and analyze ideas submitted and voted on by users in three community-based innovation forums, develop an algorithm for efficiently and effectively filtering good ideas from bad, and test the predictive power of the algorithm on other community-based innovation forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An increasingly common mantra in many organizations is that good ideas can come from unlikely places. Spurred by the success of design firms such as IDEO and Herbst, LaZar, and Bell, many organizations – large and small – are beginning to look to the users of their products and services for good ideas that might translate into new innovation. Turning to users and other commentators as a source of potential good ideas is made easy with the use of web-based crowdsourcing platforms. The term "crowdsourcing" was coined in 2006 and defined as a way to harness the creative solutions of a distributed network of individuals (Howe, 2008). Crowdsourcing is based on a framework of collective intelligence, which holds that knowledge is the most accurate when it consists of inputs from a distributed group of people .A good deal of research has shown how good ideas harnessed from the collective wisdom of crowds can be turned into sources of innovation for organizations. 

 The most popular way to source good ideas from a crowd on the web has been for organizations to create virtual communities of users who submit ideas for new products, processes or services (or revisions to told products or services) and those ideas are voted upon by members of the community. By relying on the crowd to determine whether an idea is good – as evidenced by the crowd’s voting behavior – the hope is that organizations will be able to more efficiently find new combinations of knowledge than if they relied solely on their own internal research and develop efforts With the popularity of user-generated content, the personalization appeal of products/ services, and the emergence of information and communication technologies, a variety of online communities have come into existence on the web. IBM's “Global Innovation Jam,” Adidas's “miadidas,” Threadless’ “Muji's Design Competition,” Dell's “IdeaStorm,” and Starbuck's “MyStarbucksIdeas.com” are just a few examples of virtual communities that organizations have created in an attempt to harness the wisdom of the crowd for problem-solving, products innovation and service improvements. Despite the optimism associated with crowdsourcing initiatives, empirical research suggests that the number of “good” ideas organizations ultimately source from online communities is still rather small.

This study examined three large online crowdsourcing communities to explore how organizations might be able to more effectively harness the power of the crowd to find good ideas. The findings showed  that in online, idea-generating communities there are many good ideas to be found, but the organization does not have sufficient time or resources to attend to them all to sort the wheat from the chaff. Thus, the major problem organizations face in culling good ideas from online communities is attention. Typically, voting is the primary mechanism organizations use to focus their attention on particular ideas; organizations use the quantity of votes an idea receives as a proxy for the idea’s “goodness” and pay disproportionate attention to those ideas that garner many votes  The major shortcoming to this approach is that empirical evidence suggests that many ideas submitted to an online user community receive many votes; consequently, there is not a strong correlation between the number of votes an idea receives and the likelihood that the idea will be accepted and implemented by the organization.

We found that organizations can identify ideas that are “good” not by attending to the number of votes they receive, but by attending to the composition of the collective that votes for them. This second assumption is based on a conceptualization of a voting collective as an emergent virtual team. Recently, a good deal of research into team design has shown that the structural composition of a team can explain variations in the team’s ability to generate good ideas. In short there are certain team structures that increase the likelihood that the team will generate a good idea. Conceptualizing a collective of voters as an emergent virtual team allows us to explore a number of hypotheses that will help us to identify whether ideas that are voted to be “good” by emergent virtual teams with particular structures are the ideas upon which organizations may wish to spend their limited resources of attention.
